author: sky.cactus
content: Normally I don't override other EIP editor decisions, but I feel pretty strongly that it was inappropriate for <@543900561460822016> to allow EIP-5000 to have that number.

author: sky.cactus
content: The evidence is incredibly strong in pointing to the author at least running a number sniping bot, and at worst also running a spam bot to drive the numbers up.

author: sky.cactus
content: Issue #4999 was a spam bot (since deleted) and within the same exact minute #5000 was created.

author: sky.cactus
content: cc <@689161464829050960> since you also commented on the PR.

author: sky.cactus
content: Spammers are a serious problem, and if this person was also the spam issue creator I would advocate for banning their primary account from the repository entirely.  We can't prove that though, but at least we shouldn't allow them to benefit from Sybil attacks against the repository.

author: sky.cactus
content: Looking at the PR history, it appears the author just blatantly ignored Sam's number assignment and lightclient didn't notice it since GitHub showed it as resolved.

author: sky.cactus
content: This makes me want to just delete the whole EIP in retaliation for what appears to be a blatant attack.

author: sky.cactus
content: cc <@425279588009246720> as well since your name shows up in the discussion.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think given the evidence, I would want to hear a pretty strong defense from the author to not have the EIP deleted and them banned from the repository.  I can't see any reasonable explanation how this wasn't intentional.

author: samwilsn
content: Self-admittedly a sniping bot

author: samwilsn
content: Matt and I spoke about it. I didn't have a big enough problem with them getting a particular number to care that much.

author: sky.cactus
content: I have a *huge* problem with it.  https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/5255

author: sky.cactus
content:
1. They number sniped.
2. They ignored number assignment by editor.
3. An editor is a co-author.
4. They *may* also have run a spam bot.

author: sky.cactus
content: To me this is an active attacker and should be dealt with most harshly.  This feeling is magnified many fold because an editor is a co-author and editors should be held to a far higher standard than regular users.

author: sky.cactus
content: If an editor actually executed the attack I would lobby to have them removed as an editor as we don't want people in positions of power who are inclined to abuse that power.  Since they are just a co-author I'm assuming for the moment that they were unaware of the shenanigans because I am a fan of giving benefit of the doubt, but I think because of the association this case should be handled with extreme prejudice.

author: sky.cactus
content: <@689161464829050960> We should move the EIPW bot over `ethereum/eipw` and the action to `ethereum/eipw-action` or `ethereum/eip-bot` I think?

author: lightclient
content:
I asked them to go ahead and update they're EIP and resolved the number conversation. The authors are extremely valuable contributors to the space and I don't want to fight them about the number. In the past we gave EIP-3000 away despite the author opening the PR with no content, I felt this was a similar enough of a situation to accept the EIP.

So yes, 1) they sniped it - is that explicitly against the rules though? And if it were, is it even enforceable? 2) I asked them to update offline - I should have communicated over the issue, but I had also asked Sam in the past about the number and he said didn't feel strongly enough to fight about it and I already had a channel open with the authors discussing the numbering and a few other issues so I just mentioned a few things to fix over that channel. 3) Alex is an editor, but even more so, he is a valuable contributor to ethereum. I'd rather not nickel and dime long term, trusted contributors to the protocol over eip numbering. 4) it's possible they created some spam issues before 5000, but the others have assured me this isn't the case and I don't have any other option to take their word for it

author: sky.cactus
content: We have been seeing more and more number sniping lately, and I am starting to suspect there is even more that we miss because it isn't *painfully* obvious (e.g., 5000 in the same minute as a spammer is pretty obvious, but a nice palindrome that is 30 minutes after a legitimate issue is less obvious).

author: sky.cactus
content: Currently, when authors do this there are no repercussions whatsoever, which means there is no risk in just trying it.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think we need to have there be *some* risk to this behavior.

author: sky.cactus
content: What bothers me more about this one than the sniping though is the blatant disregard of the editor assigned number and the fact that Alex is a co-author.

author: sky.cactus
content: I have an incredibly strong stance against abuse of power as that is how we maintain legitimacy.  With your past exploitation of the process to snipe an EIP number, and now Alex being on a snipe that was even contested by other editors, it feels like we are on a very bad path and we need a strong course correct.

author: lightclient
content: I take responsibility for their disregard of the editor assignment - they had messaged me privately about the number and after discussion with Sam I gave them the go ahead to use 5000

author: sky.cactus
content: This makes things even worse...

author: sky.cactus
content: It means EIP number assignment is turning into an old boys club where you just gotta know the right person and you can get what you want.

author: sky.cactus
content: This is exactly the class of thing that leads to rampant corruption in governments, favor trading and knowing the right people to skirt the rules and get away with bad behavior.

author: sky.cactus
content: To an outside observer, we now have Alex, Matt, and Sam all colluding in some backroom deal to get number 5000 (prime real estate).

author: sky.cactus
content: And they would largely be right (which makes it so much worse!)

author: lightclient
content: To be clear, Sam wasn't involved in anyway beyond me asking him several weeks ago if he felt strongly about the renumbering

author: sky.cactus
content: Yeah, that is why I said "largely" right.  ðŸ˜„  Unfortunately, the nuance is likely lost on the casual observer.

author: sky.cactus
content: And Sam *was* involved in the backroom discussion aspect (rather than public discourse).

author: lightclient
content: It was involuntary though fwiw

author: lightclient
content: I don't like this situation but I didn't feel like they had broken an explicit rule and was inclined to give them the number on the basis of their contributions to the space over the last 7 years

author: lightclient
content: I would've preferred we just not go after shiny numbers anymore, but unfortunately people still desire them

author: sky.cactus
content: To remain credibly neutral, I am of the opinion that repeat contributors (and especially EIP editors) should get even *less* leeway.

author: sky.cactus
content: I would fight tooth and nail to stop Vitalik from getting a nice number if he tried for it, for example.  To the point of forking Ethereum or building a competitor.

author: sky.cactus
content: Ethereum: Micah's Original Vision

author: lightclient
content: Ethereum: Micah's Fair Numbering Vision

author: samwilsn
content: Agreed.

author: timbeiko
content: The thing is Vitalik being an author _makes_ the number good ðŸ˜›

author: sky.cactus
content: Like Chuck Norris?

author: sky.cactus
content: I think if we are going to let this issue off with just a number change, we should *at least* pick the worst number possible.  I'm thinking 5159, because it is so easily confused with 1559 and your searches for it will probably auto-correct to 1559.

author: samwilsn
content: Heh. Why not 4998, like I originally suggested?

author: sky.cactus
content: It still has a double number, and is not terrible.

author: samwilsn
content: Sure, whatever floats your boat.

author: samwilsn
content: Who has permissions to do that on `ethereum`? I can add them as admins on my repos to make the move.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think <@642887713246150666> knows who to contact.

author: poojaranjan
content: Let me try reach out the team. <@689161464829050960> I will DM you.

author: samwilsn
content: Thanks!
